section.hand:
To my L Treasuro
r
e 14 Au
g
89

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 14 August To my Lord Tresurer
It may please yo
r
L. It should seeme by conference
t
I &
M
r
Gilpin
have hadd w
th
some in this place that there ar those w
ch
will
endeavour to have hir
Ma
ty
moved to appoint
Count Maurice
Lieuten
a
t
Generall of hir highnes forces into these countreyes, w
ch
I cannot
write as a thing assured, but consyderyng
e
sons & theyr maner of
communica
o
n, I have so good cause to suspect yt as I thought yt
very necessary to be im
ted w
th
yo
r
L. wheth
r
yt be intended that
e
matt
r
should be moved by some wellwillers of
e Count, or so handled
oth
r
wise as yt might onely seeme to
ceed from hir Ma
ty
, I cannot
well conjecture, nor yet
ceave by theyr speches wheth
r
yt would bee
an acceptable matter to
e
g
nall
States
, albeit it is p
r
tended
t
yt
would be utterly disliked. The
ties
t
ministered occasyon of this
conference ar accounted very honest, well affected to her Ma
tye
& of good reputa
o
n, But not to c
o
ber yo
r
L w
th
mayny circ
u
stances
They lamented very much
e feeble state of thes countreys for want of
good order in government, & unfayned correspondence w
th
her Ma
tye
w
th
many speeches to
t
purpose, conceeding upon yt
t
unles hir Ma
tye
could be [woon] to take
e soverainty upon hir, or lay some oth
r
plott
w
th
this people,
en is put in practise at this p
nt
yt would be
unpossible for this countrey to hold out long against
e Enemy.
Being heerupon moved by us to deliv
r
what oth
r
plott might be
proposed, they thought that there could no bett
r
course be taken
en for hir Ma
tye
to accept of Count Maurice for hir lieutenant
g
nall
, & to declare to
e Provinces
t
in respect of
e ill accord
w
ch
hath bin ever between her highnes chief ministers & them, shee can
be pleased to comyt
e regiment of hir Auxiliary forces to some
principall
son of theyr nation who together w
th
e
counsell of State
being better established, might take such order in all thing
as
were requysyt. this they thought would make very muche for
e
[concurement] of
e commune cause & occasyon a greater union between
hir Ma
ty
& these countreys. They added w
th
all
t
yt would also
cause
e matche to go forward between
e
Countesse of Beuren
&
e
Count Hohenlo
. whom they thought yt also likely
t
Count Maurice in
t
caise would appoint his Lieutenant. And likewise
t
Count
Maurice might be drawen by that meanes to matche w
th
some Englishe
house, & knitt a
fect &
petuall knott of amity & alliance
between
e two nations. Upon these & oth
r
like
tinent discourses
we demaunded, were yt so
t
her Ma
ty
could be in duced to like of
such a notion. whether they thought yt fytt
t
her highnes of her
self should make offer of such a singular favour to
e Count
Considering the Coldenes
devotion
w
ch
his excellency hath alwaies shewed
in furthering of hir Ma
ties
causes, &
e slender courtesy
t
all those of
fol.77v
o
r
nation had receaved at his hand
. Wh
r
upon they made me
answer
t
there would be no doubt but
t
yf
e Count
might stand assured
t
e offer of his service in
t
behalf
would be well accepted hir Ma
ty
should quickly
ceave
t
he would therby addict him self to [frame] all his cowrses to hir Ma
ties
contenta
o
n.
e finall answere to all these
speeches was,
t
we knew no oth
r
by
but that hir Ma
tie
ment to continew
e government of hir subject
in hir
owne [ministers], &
t
yf
e Countrey heer hath not receaved
t
assistance & ayd, as they expected
e fault was in theyr
owne preposterous &
vers proceeding. Nev
r
theles yf we
might either
ceave in
e Count himself or by any of his
friend
as from him,
t
he were willing to have
e motion made
to her Ma
ty
, ther should be no difficulty made to
s
ve his turne
in
t
behalf. Since this talk was between us, I have
bin informed,
t
the self same
ties have had a great deale
of conference w
th
a principall consaillor of
e Count, about
e same dessigne. Also
e Count, I have noted of late
hath conversed here w
th
us more familiarly & co
r
teously then he
was accustomed heertofor, And as
S
r
Francis Vere
hath written
to mee since his being at
Gorch
u
both hee & Count Hohenlo have
intreated him &
e rest w
th
extraordinary kyndenes. There are oth
r
conjecturall tokens besides by w
ch
yt may be gathered almost
playnly
t
e Count & his friend
ar purposed to deale
directly or indirectly w
th
hir Ma
ty
&
t
they are in hope to
obtaine their des ire & though I ca
n
ot und
r
stand
t
the g
nall
states ar made acquainted w
th
e matter, yet I do assure
my self
t
there are among them some whose counsel ys
[.]. And whether yt may not be a spetiall occasyon
t
they have bin of late so ov
r
insolent & headstrong th
r
by
haps
to make hir Ma
ty
weary of hir owne courses & to work
e
government of all to
e Count & them selves. I leave yt
to yo
r
L. judgement togeth
r
w
th
e Consydera
o
n of this whole
advertisement, wherof to write my opinion, although I knowe
yt is nedles, ye
t
I cannot but intimate thus much, that yf the Count wold cary him self [no] oth
r
wise then he ought
& those w
th
whom we had
is conference would seeme to assure us
as far as my slender capacity can [reatche], both hir Ma
ty
might
be eased of a great deal of trouble, &
e Countrey here
much bett
r
assisted. Thus beseeching yo
r
L yf in
fol.78r
this motion there by any thing materiall to acquaint
M
r
Secretary
w
th
yt.
I take my humble leave. From
e Hage Aug 89
